abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact is substantial. Lessons highlight the need for clear
            project objectives at appraisal, when the development
            objectives depend on implementation of a broad program,
            enhanced by an appropriate design which should include both
            a project, and program monitoring criteria, including the
            joint review arrangements of the program by the cooperating
            partners. Such monitoring, and evaluation requires
            measurable, verifiable indicators for a fair assessment of
            project performance. Moreover, on addressing sexually
            transmitted diseases (STD), and HIV/AIDS epidemic, a shift
            from the narrow biomedical paradigm to a development one is
            required. Underlying the biological transmission of HIV, and
            STDs is a huge issue of social vulnerability, thus a
            programmatic approach is better suited to consolidate
            efforts, aimed at reducing, and mitigating the impact of the
            epidemic, focused on the underlying vulnerability issues.
            Greater efforts are also needed to involve both the private
            sector in the provision of services, and public-private
            partnerships collaborative efforts in sharing costs,
            emphasizing the promotion of an enabling sociopolitical
            environment. In addition, decentralized project
            implementation requires strong political commitment, and the
            decentralization of fiscal responsibility should be matched
            with authority, carefully supported by institutional
            capacity building. Finally, financial management should
            develop mechanisms for financing nongovernmental
            organizations, and, financial accounts, and reporting
            requirement systems should be recorded in a uniformed manner.
